transcription.text: [ Music ]
>> Okay, so thank you.
Today I'm going to present you all solutions for efficient
and scalable off-chain execution for arbitrary application
for Ethereum.
So we are IEXAC.
I am Jil Fedak.
So first, let's thanks and give a big close to the team
because they worked really hard to be ready for their country
and having this release ready.
Some of us are here.
We are at the booth just over there at the outside
of this conference room.
So we are now about 13 people in Lyon in France
and we are going to be a little more formal joining us
by the end of this year.
So that's a wonderful team and I'm really proud of them.
So what we are doing at IEXAC, we are doing the Ethereum-based
decentralized cloud computing which means that we are using
the Ethereum blockchain to create a decentralized marketplace
for cloud computing resources.
So those computing resources that can be what you typically found
in a cloud, so servers, applications and data sets.
And so we are using the Ethereum blockchain to advertise
and provide those computing resources.
So you can fix it as a sort of Airbnb for servers
but without Airbnb.
And of course, in this case, this is the blockchain
that creates those peer-to-peer interactions
between the users and the providers.
So having a decentralized cloud, why does it matter?
For two main reasons, I would say.
The first one is that we can see that in this conference,
there are more and more new decentralized application
and this coming a new decentralized economy.
And so we now need an actual infrastructure
to support those new applications.
That's the first reason.
And the second reason is that this decentralized cloud,
the infrastructure is going to be very different.
It's going to be distributed.
And probably compared to the centralized cloud,
we're going to have many advantages
because the marketplace is certainly going to be much cheaper.
It's going to be distributed.
So it's going to be greener and certainly more efficient
because the data are going to be closer
to the consumer or producer.
So what are the applications we are targeting?
First, we are looking at the blockchain-based distributed
application, the DAPs, to the application that
executes on the blockchain.
And you know that the Ethereum virtual machine
offers very few computing capacities to those applications.
The processing is very low.
It's extremely expensive for storage and computation.
And so they need off-chain computation
to have an actual-- I mean, to be a really important application.
The second category is what we call the legacy application.
Those are the applications running now on the cloud
that would eventually come to our infrastructure
because we can offer a better price performance ratio.
So here we are thinking of applications
such as simulations, machine learning, finance,
freely rendering, and so forth.
And the next category are those applications
to data as close as possible to the origin.
So people talk about the decoding that fog or edge computing.
So with one of the key, the fundamental point
in the protocol is the iExact Ocon, it's called RLC.
So this is a pure utility token.
This is the way people can enter the network
and use the computing resources that
are in this decentralized cloud.
And this is also the way a provider for resources
or application are being paid.
And this is very important also because it
allows to create incentives in the protocol.
And that's something that is really new compared.
That can be eventually an advantage compared
to the existing cloud and the way we're doing this.
So we issued this token on my net and last up
pre-learn 2017.
So the roadmap, where are we now?
So we started about six months ago.
We are now at the first version of iExact.
So the way when you create a distributed infrastructure,
it's a kind of a chicken and egg problem.
Do you first start to have the machines
and then in the network and then you
try to find some application to run on this machine?
Or do you first start to with the applications
and then once you know the application,
then you can create a relevant architecture.
So when we design this roadmap for iExact,
we design it by starting with the application,
in particular with the DABS.
And then later, that would come in next May or next June,
we'll open the network to the servers.
So it means that at the moment, you
can push any applications, but they
are going to be executed on all machines.
So somehow you have to trust us.
But later on, in next June, it will
be any machine that can compute any applications.
So we are very pleased today because we are not
seeing the first version of iExact.
And it's called the wanderer.
So the way we are naming the iExact version,
we take characters from the Chinese novel,
what I'm arguing.
So I don't know if you know this novel, I love it.
It's a story of people who were
robust, who were well against the central authority
in middle-aged China.
And here, the wandererized the number 36
among the rebel.
So this version one is basically a software development
kit that allows you to deploy your application on iFirium
and iExact.
So I'm going to present you how it works.
So this is a video, but really I encourage you
to try the tutorial by yourself.
It's much more fun than watching a video.
So what you see here is actually a screencast.
It's actually a screencast of a web page.
And so you don't have to install anything
to do the tutorial.
You just visit the web page.
And the tutorial is about six, I mean,
from 10 to half an hour, depending on what kind of test
that you're using.
So when you use DSD--
so first you install DSDK.
That's very similar to Truffert.
So if you are used to Truffert, you
will find that it's exactly almost the same.
Then we are here with this tutorial.
We are playing with a toy application.
Of course, it's factorial.
But if you are using-- if you're
still in the SDK on your own machine,
you will be able to use any kind of application.
So when we start, we first get some ETH,
just to be able to deploy the contract.
We're using a function which is called IEXEC deployed.
So IEXEC deployed those two things.
On the one hand, it combines all the Solidity smart contract.
It will deploy it on Ethereum.
And the second thing that it does
is that it pushes your existing application to IEXEC.
And what you just seen here, it's the application,
what it has been deployed on IEXEC.
So now what you will see here is that we're going to use
the application as your user.
So for doing this, we first retrieve some RHC tokens.
We allow the contract to expand those tokens.
And what we're doing now is that we submit a job.
So once you submit a job, you can see that--
I'm going to stop here.
You can see that-- so when you submit a job,
the job here is being computed.
This is why you see pending and pending.
So it has been accelerated.
But of course, it takes much more--
it can take more time.
And when it's done-- so this is the hash of the transaction
that you got from the smart contract.
And once it's done, you can see that you finish the job.
And this is the result of the computation.
And you can see on the Explorer.
So this is an Explorer we provide to see
what's going on between outchain and offchain.
And you can see the result of the computation
in the smart contract, or you can retrieve it using
our command line tool.
So what is the deployment strategy for Runderout?
So what you have seen now is that it's running now
on Robston and on the other test net.
So we are going to deploy it in the coming weeks.
So first, we'll deploy the SDK with all the application.
The next two weeks, we are going to create an app store
so that it makes the application for the end user
much more user-friendly, because at the moment,
they have to interact with the smart contract.
And later on, by the end of the year,
we are going to deploy this app store on mainnet,
which means that developers using the iXX
will actually be able to earn IAC tokens.
So what happens under the hood, what we do
is that those computations are actually executed
and distributed in fast-search.
So we call worker the machines that join this in fast-search,
join this network, and that provide their CPU time
to execute the application.
And so we organize those workers in the worker pool
a little bit like you have miners and minor pool.
It's exactly the same idea.
But here, any worker can execute any arbitrary application,
and not just mining.
And what we do is that we have an Oracle
that looks at what's happening on the blockchain,
on your smart contract.
And each time the Oracle detects that there's
a transaction, the smart contract,
it's executed to correspond to the application on the workers.
So for version two, it means that any computing resources
can join the network.
And also, of course, it causes a lot of issues,
in particular with respect to security.
So since this September, we have launched an official research
program that has started very well, actually.
So we are working on two things.
One is proof of contribution, which is basically
a consensus protocol to verify that the execution that
were off-shelled, everybody agrees that the computation is
OK before proceeding to the payments.
That's one.
And the second is some security research
that we are doing to protect both the application
and the remote machine.
So actually proof of contribution
is done by a PhD student, Adria,
who was a student at the economic equilibrium.
For a more long-term perspective,
we think that we are really lacking some good experimental
tools to understand the performance of those blockchain
based distributed systems.
So we are starting PhD thesis in collaboration
with a lab in France, which is called Lawyer.
And those people are really experts
in emulation of very large parallel distributed systems.
So why do you want to do emulation?
Because it allows you to do experiments,
but with an exact thing software stack.
So it's much closer to the reality than just doing simulation.
So it's not only for us.
I think it will be very interesting also
for the Ethereum community to have such tools.
Basically, you can test your software very rapidly
on tens of thousands of virtual nodes.
So some words about proof of contribution.
So we started this in September, about.
We now have a knowledge solution.
It's based basically on stacking and reputation.
So Adria come up with a very interesting protocol.
It's very simple.
Basically, the idea is that for each execution
you submit your associate disexactuation
with a confidence threshold.
And so workers, they have both a reputation.
And reputation is gained according to their past work.
So if the task succeeded or not.
And they also have to stack some money, to stack some token.
And so what we do is that each time we receive some results,
we compare the results and we compute a new confidence
threshold.
And if we can pass this threshold,
then the result is accepted by the submitter.
And so task is duplicated or replicating
as long as the confidence threshold is not made.
And so at the end, what you have is workers
will behave correctly and discard the received payment.
And some will did wrong because maybe they
tried to steal some money.
In this case, we punished them.
We take their stack and we distribute the stack
amongst the workers we did correctly.
So the good thing with this protocol
is that it's actually very simple.
So it's simple to implement and then to verify also.
And it will be also simple to optimize.
So at the moment, Adrian is doing the performance evaluation.
And we are quite happy with these early results.
The other thing when you do an execution on a machine
you don't trust is the security.
And so there are two aspects here.
So one is the sandbox.
Sandbox thing is the technique that protect the workers
from their application.
So imagine the application is a virus.
What you want to do is to execute this application
in sort of a restraint environment where you control
what the application is actually going to do.
So this is something that is not new.
It takes this for you actually.
There are many ways to do that.
It can be at kernel level of actualization.
Basically here, the main issues are more with respect
to deployment.
How is it going to be installed by the machine
joining the network?
The second thing that is really new,
the second thing is how you're going
to protect the application from the worker.
If you don't trust the machine, how the machine is good,
there can be some privacy issue.
So up to now, we had no solution for that.
But since sometimes there is a new solution that appears,
it's called enclave.
In particular, thanks to Intellite SJ,
which is a new instruction set that
are now deployed on Intel processors,
we now have a solution for that.
So an enclave, this is basically a memory space that
is for you, where you execute your application.
And even root on the machine, even if you have privilege
access on the machine, you cannot access to this memory
because fully encrypted.
And the way to decrypt the memories and secure
them in the processor.
So what we are doing now is that we're
evaluating two solutions to execute our application
within an enclave.
One is called a SCON, something that has been published
at OSDI this year.
And this allows you to run a Linux container in the enclave.
There is another solution that we are looking at.
It's called a Graphen SJX.
It's the same idea, but instead of a container,
it relies on library OS or a microkernel.
It's almost the same thing here.
So a couple of things that are coming in the very next future.
Just after that, we're going to run an AskMeer
config on Reddit.
Then we're going to participate to the supercomputing
conference, even though we are not with cryptocurrency.
We still love those big machines that you have at
supercomputing.
It'll be in Denver, Colorado.
We're going to organize a series of meetups starting
with Lion so that people can get in the technology
and use that and start to develop their own application.
By being the sample, hopefully, the app store for distributed
application will go live.
And so you will be able to publish your application
in this app store.
By the sample, we're also going to launch a DAB
development challenge.
The idea is really to give bounties to developers so that
they can propose us some cool application.
And we will be really happy to support them.
And by the next year or so, we're going to launch another
program, which is the IXX summer of code.
I don't know if you're familiar with Google summer of code.
The same idea.
So it allows students, everyone on Earth, to work on any
subject related to decentralization.
So it's not only for IXX, it's for everyone.
So as a conclusion, we've been really happy to present you
this first step for IXX.
Hope you will try it.
Meters, where we have a booth.
And happy DevCon.
Happy Iking.
